steps.title: Think of what kind of movements your characters will be doing, step by step.
steps.content: Think of what kind of movements your characters will be doing, step by step. In the first stage, plot out four to six boxes on a piece of paper and write your first actions in each box, with the caption under them. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Decide on the angle for each frame.
steps.content: Decide on the angle for each frame. Close-up or background-shot? Horizontal or vertical, maybe slanted? How does this affect the scene? [2] X Research source

steps.title: Rewrite the panels on a different sheet of paper and fit them together [for the American manga artist, panel them left-to-right].
steps.content: Rewrite the panels on a different sheet of paper and fit them together [for the American manga artist, panel them left-to-right]. If you are leaning towards traditional format, right-to-left panels are a nice idea. [3] X Research source Decide in this part of the process what frames bleed out from the edges, but be careful to keep the important captions and drawings inside a "safe-zone". Now, there doesn't have to be a gap between boxes like in American Marvel Comics. Usually, the borders separating each panel are just thin yet bold black lines. In some cases, the borders of a given panel will be left out entirely. This technique is called 'bleeding out' frames. [4] X Research source

steps.title: This process can be done several times until the manga-ka sees the page as fit.
steps.content: This process can be done several times until the manga-ka sees the page as fit. After you've made the perfect page, ink it with inking multi-liner pens [or G-pens, whichever you prefer]. Copic and Pigma are recommended highly.
